content.description: Starts with both hands matched on the furthest sloper hold to the right of the “Spud Crack.”  Move left on pinches/side pulls with technical foot placements. The crux is the left shoulder/gaston move into the start hold of the classic “Fry Problem.”
content.location: Located on the Fry Boulder between Cap Rock and Ryan Campground.

content.description:
Good edges with undercut, sloping feet quickly reaches a juggy crack with bomber holds which soon dies out, after which sloping dishes lead to the top. Note: this problem is also the downclimb for the boulder.

This problem was originally called "Into the Fire".
content.location:
Located on the right side of the Fry Boulder, about 5' right of the

Fry Problem

.

content.description: This is a run-and-jump problem which goes for a good edge above a smooth scooped section of rock; once the jug is gained it's easy to the top. Can also be done with a big cheatstone or pad stack (being tall helps).
content.location:
Left of center on the north face and just left of the

Fry Problem

.

content.description:
Start with a high pinch/lieback and smooth, undercut feet, pull into the rock and use creative body english to reach some high sloping edges. Bust left to a good edge, then stem and reach for a sculpted jug and on to the juggy top.

Downclimb the juggy crack just right to descend.
content.location:
Up the center of the boulder and about 5' left of

Spud Crack

.

content.description:
This problem climbs a sloping, grainy arete that requires some liebacking, proper body positioning and making use of the power of positive friction. Fairly grainy throughout it's length with some semi-commiting moves with your feet on the very edge of the arete; a foot slip in the wrong spot could skin you alive.

Downclimb the juggy

Spud Crack

to descend the boulder.

This problem was originally called "Frying Pan".
content.location:
Located on the left arete of the Fry Boulder, about 15' left of the

Fry Problem

.
